Wolfgang Vogel, the shadowy lawyer who for years embodied the only channel of communication between the two states set up on German soil after the second world war, has died aged 82, some months after a heart attack ruined his health. The supreme go-between also brokered deals between the Soviet and western blocs in the depths of the cold war, taking money from both sides as he arranged "spy swaps" and bought freedom for many thousands of political prisoners and ordinary East Germans.

Vogel's pathway to equivocal fame and fortune opened in 1959, when he was approached by the East German wife of Rudolf Abel, a Soviet masterspy caught by the Americans in New York two years earlier, tried, convicted and imprisoned. In 1960, American U2 spyplane flights over the Soviet Union, which had been going on for four years with impunity because the Russians lacked a high-flying anti-aircraft missile, were finally exposed. A technological leap enabled them to shoot down the aircraft piloted by Francis Gary Powers.

President Eisenhower tried to lie his way out by claiming the U2 was on a routine weather patrol, but Nikita Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, triumphantly produced recovered parts of the aircraft, including instruments and films - and the pilot, who had survived unharmed. A summit between the two leaders in Paris was loudly cancelled by Khrushchev, who turned up just to walk out. Powers was sent to jail after a show trial.

Two years on, Vogel took the leading part in constructing a delicate deal whereby Abel was released to the Russians in exchange for Powers. The swap took place on the Glienicke bridge, which straddled the border between east and west Berlin on the divided city's outskirts. Thriller writers and film-makers soon turned this into a long-lasting cliché, born out by subsequent real-life events at the same spot, which became a symbol of freedom and one of the most famous bridges in the world.

Less spectacularly, but at the same time, the East Germans released an American doctoral student and alleged spy - another Vogel client - at that other notorious cold war symbol, Checkpoint Charlie, a Berlin border crossing to the American sector of the city. Vogel had truly found his metier.

Perhaps his most famous coup was the exchange release from the Soviet Union in 1986 of the Jewish dissident Anatoly Scharansky, the future Israeli minister Nathan Sharansky. The diminutive ex-prisoner took a running jump over the white border line painted on the deck of the Glienicke bridge in what became a huge media event. Vogel's main client on that occasion was the US government.

He was born in Lower Silesia, German until 1945 and then handed over to Poland, whereupon the Vogel family moved to the Soviet zone of Germany. This would become the German Democratic Republic (East Germany) in 1949, in response to the creation of the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany) from the American, British and French occupation zones. Vogel studied law at Karl Marx University, where he married Eva Anlauf; their son, Manfred, was born in 1947. They also had a daughter, Lilo, but were divorced in 1967 - after Vogel had negotiated their emigration from East to West Germany.

He had qualified as a lawyer in 1949 and joined the East German ministry of Justice three years later.

His mentor, a judge, fled to West Germany after the abortive anti-communist uprising in East Berlin in 1953, and sent Vogel an invitation to join him. This was intercepted by the Stasi, the fearsome East German state security and espionage agency, which promptly forced him into service, initially as a "voluntary collaborator" or informer, and soon as an active legal agent for the regime abroad. The two new German states had turned their backs on each other in 1949 for a quarter of a century. Relations were not bad - they simply did not exist officially. It was only when Chancellor Willy Brandt's Ostpolitik of reconciliation between Germany and its former enemies made headway in the early 1970s that the two states exchanged "representations" or quasi-embassies.

Brandt resigned in 1974 when an East German spy, Günter Guillaume, was discovered in his inner circle of advisers, put on trial and imprisoned. After much hard work by Vogel, who had developed close relations with Helmut Schmidt, Brandt's successor, Guillaume was released without publicity in 1981 at a village on the intra-German border. Vogel, who was also on very good terms with Erich Honecker, the East German leader, was waiting to welcome him back to East Germany. The communist state's most successful known agent complained that he had hoped to see Vogel rather sooner. By this time the manipulative, ingratiating lawyer was a highly skilled networker and negotiator.

Meanwhile the regime was in desperate need of hard currency, and developed a particularly cynical method of acquiring it: the sale of individual freedom, for which the West Germans proved ready and willing to pay. The 34,000 "political prisoners" whose release for cash payments Vogel negotiated were commonly classed as such for trying or just openly desiring a move to the west. The 215,000 ordinary East Germans whose transfer westward helped to bring in $2.4bn in hard currency were often elderly, thus relieving the East German state of the need to pay their pensions, also funded by West Germany. But at least a lot of families were reunited as a result.

It was an amoral, even brutal, exercise in realpolitik which made Vogel a very rich man as the fees poured in from east and west, the two Germanys and the two superpowers alike. But in 1989 the Berlin wall came down, the communist regime and its Stasi octopus fell and Vogel's services were no longer required. Unsurprisingly he moved west himself, to Schliersee, a pretty lakeside resort in the Bavarian Alps, with Helga, his former assistant and second wife. It was widely reported at the time that when the intra-German border defences were demolished upon German unification, the east German wild boar population, always in search of the best pickings, did the same.

Police in Birmingham appealed to rival gangs to stay calm last night after a 24-year-old man was shot dead, the latest in a spate of shootings in the inner city area of Newtown.

West Midlands police said Dimitri Foskin was shot once in the chest shortly before 10.15pm on Saturday in Hockley Close, north of the city centre, which local residents said was frequented by drug dealers. He was taken by ambulance to City hospital where he was later pronounced dead.

The victim was unemployed and had lived nearby with his mother. Police said he had been socialising with friends and cousins and had visited a number of houses in and around the close with at least two other people before leaving one of the properties alone. It was then that he was killed.

Officers said last night said they were aware of gang rivalries in the community, but added that they did not have a motive for the killing and at this early stage were not linking the attack to gang warfare.

It is the third fatal shooting in the Newtown area in the past nine months. In March Nehemiah Bryce, 27, of Winson Green, was shot dead just a few hundred metres away, in Rodway Close, after a chase. On December 23 last year, Assar Joseph Mohammed Tomlinson was shot dead during a row outside the King of the Road pub in Hospital Street.

On April 1, a teenager and another man were injured when a youth burst into the City Internet shop and fired several shots.

"It is a tragic loss of life," said Chief Superintendent Mick Treble. "We would like to send out an appeal for calm. Where individuals have frictions between them we would ask them to work with the police and with other agencies instead of young people sadly losing their lives. A man who was a son, a brother and a friend has been lost and clearly that should be enough to make people think this is a crime that should not continue to occur. We are aware there are tensions between rival gangs in the community and are alive to that issue, and are working with the city council to enable young people to come together to resolve their differences."

Hockley Close was yesterday cordoned off while police conducted house to house inquiries and officers appealed for witnesses to come forward. A blue tent stood on the driveway outside the semi-detached house where Foskin was found.

A 26-year-old woman from the Newtown area of Birmingham who knew him said Foskin was "lovely, funny and gentle".

"I have no idea why somebody would want to do something like this," she said. "He was caring and laid back and he had a very close family. He was a family boy. The people who have done this can run, but they can't hide, and hopefully justice will be done.

Local residents yesterday complained that the area had recently become more dangerous, with guns increasingly prevalent. "It's all drug and gang-related," said Colin Murdoch, 46, a lorry driver. "There's just not enough policing in the area. We need more officers on the beat."

A 36-year-old woman, who did not wish to be named, said: "You only have to go to the shops to see people dealing on the corner. Holocaust memorial daubed with swastikas

Vandals have painted 11 swastikas on some of the 2,700 grey slabs of Berlin's Holocaust memorial. Police said the red and black Nazi symbols were discovered by a guard at the monument on Saturday and were immediately wiped off the seven slabs affected. The memorial to the Holocaust's 6 million Jewish victims is a field of concrete slabs situated close to Berlin's Brandenburg Gate. It opened to the public in 2005 and is freely accessible around the clock. It has been vandalised several times. The vandalism came a week after a memorial to gay victims of the Nazis was also damaged.
Associated Press in Berlin

Canadian and Australian journalists held hostage

Two foreign journalists were kidnapped near Somalia's capital on Saturday, along with their Somali driver and two guards. Somalia's government has confirmed the kidnapping. Paris-based Reporters Without Borders has identified the journalists as Canadian Amanda Lindhout and Australian Nigel Brennan. Omar Faruk Osman, secretary general of the National Union of Somali Journalists, said: "We are appalled by this cruel abduction of journalists and call for the immediate release of our colleagues who are being held captive because of their noble work for Somali people."
Associated Press in Mogadishu

Technical fault forces Spanair plane to land

Spanair, the airline involved in a crash this week that killed 154 people in Madrid, had another technical problem yesterday with one of its planes and had to make an unscheduled landing. Air agency AENA said Spanair flight JK2565 from Barcelona to Lanzarote landed at Malaga airport after it left Barcelona at 8.10am. It was diverted an hour into the journey. The flight, with 141 passengers aboard, was then cancelled. Passengers were put up in a local hotel. Spanair told the El Periódico newspaper the stop in Malaga, on Spain's southern coast, was not an emergency landing.
Associated Press in Madrid

Gun buyback campaign aims to clean up streets

The Brazilian government has launched a gun buyback programme in an effort to take 500,000 weapons off the streets. People will be able to hand in guns with no questions asked. The government will pay between 97 and 300 reais (£32 and £100), depending on the model and condition of the gun. The programme ends in December. A similar campaign in 2004 removed at least 300,000 guns from the streets. Justice minister Tarso Genro said 45m reais was available for the programme. With 40,000 gun-related deaths a year, Brazil is considered one of the world's most violent countries.
Associated Press in Rio de Janeiro

I was intrigued recently to see a painting in the National Gallery by the Flemish artist David Teniers the Younger, in which a rich man is being led to hell through a subterranean crypt thronged with bats and snakes. Is the bat's nocturnal lifestyle enough to explain these centuries of misrepresentation? Yet while there is definitely nothing evil about bats there is something decidedly liminal. Their wings are no more than a diaphanous parchment, the thickness of a grape skin, stretched over a spider's web of finger-bone. It produces a motion so twisting and elusive you sometimes wonder, as you try to follow one in flight, whether you're seeing the actual creature or just some fading mental impression of a flying bat superimposed upon the space where one has just been.

Their echo-location system is one of those truths that outdoes fiction. Bats blast their surroundings with a machine-gun fire of high-frequency pulses then wait for the rebounded calls, which are unscrambled in the bat brain as information on the relative distances and contours of an environment. Essentially they're hearing the appearance of a place. The system is so sensitive they can detect and avoid a wire the thickness of a human hair. They can identify an insect - and judge its edibility - by the way their echoes curve around it. One is flabbergasted not just by the idea of a world sculpted by voice, but by the inner labyrinth of the bat's neurological system which allows the creature a flight of such intricate convolutions when effectively blind.

We followed our bat, probably a Daubenton's, on a bat detector, a device which converts the calls to sounds within the human range of audible frequencies. It was a thin metallic crepitation that intensified as the creature swirled down across Rockland Broad. At its closest, the bat's sounds acquired a tachycardia-like intensity and every now and then we caught the creature itself as a brief muster of skittering darkness.

Barack Obama's running mate has been fingered by CNet's Declan McCullagh in a post headed Joe Biden's pro-RIAA, pro-FBI tech voting record. The story says:

After taking over the Foreign Relations committee, Biden became a staunch ally of Hollywood and the recording industry in their efforts to expand copyright law. He sponsored a bill in 2002 that would have make it a federal felony to trick certain types of devices into playing unauthorized music or executing unapproved computer programs. Biden's bill was backed by content companies including News Corp. but eventually died after Verizon, Microsoft, Apple, eBay, and Yahoo lobbied against it.

Also:

Last year, Biden sponsored an RIAA-backed bill called the Perform Act aimed at restricting Americans' ability to record and play back individual songs from satellite and Internet radio services. (The RIAA sued XM Satellite Radio over precisely this point.)

Biden's other bills range from the Omnibus Counterterrorism Act of 1995 to the Biden Crime Bill of 2007. Of the latter, CNet says:

One section expands electronic surveillance law to permit police wiretaps in "crimes dangerous to the life, limb, and well-being of minor children." Another takes aim at Internet-based telemedicine and online pharmacies, saying that physicians must have conducted "at least one in-person medical evaluation of the patient" to prescribe medicine.

Whether the Obama/Biden ticket is more liberal than the Republican presidential candidate John McCain is open to discussion. McCain wants to expand the Patent Office and "supports efforts to crack down on piracy, both on the Internet and off".

As promised, David Beckham and a double-decker bus featured in today's closing ceremony for the 2008 Olympic Games, along with Leona Lewis, Jimmy Page and Boris Johnson. But they were a minor diversion, only briefly interrupting the second act of Zhang Yimou's Great Patriotic Pageant.

The evening opened with a countdown, an explosion of fireworks, and a potted reprise of the sort of Busby Berkeley-meets-House of Flying Daggers extravaganza invented by Zhang, the great film director, for the opening ceremony, this time involving a mere 200 drummers.

Early on there was an unscheduled collision involving a wayward monocyclist - whose machine, ingeniously enough, was a single large wheel inside which he sat and pedalled - and a small group of figures got up to resemble a dancing troupe from one of the 56 ethnic minority groups of whom the Chinese have made such play over the last fortnight. They got up, dusted themselves down, and carried on playing their parts.

During the entry of the flags, carried by athletes, Chris Hoy did his job with manly resolve and no evident sign of Scottish nationalist sentiment (indeed, he had responded earlier in the day to a Scottish politican's suggestion that the country might consider going it alone in the Olympics by remarking tartly that it could only be taken seriously when Scotland started investing money in sport).

The appearance of the athletes created the usual degree of mild interest in their leisurewear. The Italians seemed a mite overdressed in silver jackets and matching shoes, the French carried a string of tricolour bunting that made the centre of the Bird's Nest look like a village fete in the Luberon, the United States athletes - men and women - had been issued with curious white flat caps, the Canadians opted for Pucci-print beach slacks, and there appeared to be an awful lot of Dutch - or maybe orange just has a sort of spreading quality.

The medal winners from the men's marathon received their rewards and there was a stirring sight for Africa as the flags of Kenya, Morocco and Ethiopia were raised. Bouquets were presented to a dozen volunteers representing more than 70,000 young people whose unfailing politeness and good humour were even more impressive than the fireworks and the architecture which will be the image left by the 29th Games.

Jacques Rogge made a speech in which he praised "a truly exceptional Games", the very words Juan Antonio Samaranch, his predecessor as president of the International Olympic Committee, famously used about Atlanta in his closing remarks in 1996, instead of calling it - as was his habit every four years - "the best Games ever". At the time, this was taken as the most tremendous snub, which may not have been Rogge's intention.

The British national anthem was sweetly sung by a young 28-voice choir, almost half of them visibly from ethnic minorities, a sign of the approach that won London the right to host the 30th Games. The mayor of Beijing handed the Olympic flag via Rogge to the mayor of London, who failed to drop it and, as he left the podium, indulged in a decorous orgy of mutual celebration with the British athletes while they donned their pink "See you in London" jackets.

Cue the double-decker bus - not a Routemaster but a cunning replica - with Hoy, Jamie Staff and Victoria Pendleton, all gold medal winners, cycling around it like a couple of London commuters. When the doors opened a file of dancing hoodies, crossing attendants, handicapped people, binge-drinkers and schoolgirls emerged, before the sides of the bus opened out to become a piece of suburban topiary from which Lewis ascended on a lift to sing Whole Lotta Love with guitar accompaniment from the venerable Page. They were joined by a cellist, a violinist and a tracksuited Beckham, who punted a football into the crowd - a bit of a slice, one thought, perhaps into row Z - before the sequence ended in a bit of business with illuminated umbrellas and the stately withdrawal of the bus. Remarkable.

And then the hosts regained control. With the aid of a vast human pyramid and a couple of actors standing at the top of a giant airport jetway, the flame went out, ending a Games in which, to freely adapt a thought from Rogge's speech, the world looked at China, China looked at the world, and both sides drew their own conclusions.

Like so many modern conflicts, the hallmark of the latest war in Georgia is that civilians have borne the brunt of the fighting.

At the outset of this war, the Georgian military used indiscriminate and disproportionate force resulting in civilian deaths in South Ossetia. The Russian military has since used indiscriminate force in attacks in South Ossetia and in the Gori district, and has apparently targeted convoys of civilians, killing and wounding them as they have attempted to flee the conflict zones.

In parts of Georgia currently under Russian control, ongoing looting, arson attacks, and abductions by militia are terrorising the civilian population, forcing them to flee their homes and preventing displaced people from returning home.

Now that the shooting war is over, there is an urgent need for the deployment of an international security mission to help protect civilians and create a safe environment for the displaced to return home.

Protection of civilians is not only a good in itself, but can also help to prevent recurring attacks that could reignite a conflict in which – as the recent heated rhetoric in Washington, Moscow and European capitals indicates – there is much more at stake than the future of a couple of Russian backed separatist enclaves in Georgia.

A civilian protection mission in Georgia is a job well suited for the European Union. Led by France, EU diplomats and politicians have already shown initiative by brokering a ceasefire. They should now follow that up by immediately starting work on the swift deployment of a civilian protection mission that may well help that ceasefire stick.

In the past half decade the EU has deployed almost 20 missions under its European security and defence policy (ESDP). These have included full-blown military operations in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Bosnia, border-monitoring operations in Moldova and on the Gaza/Egypt border, ceasefire monitoring in Aceh in Indonesia, "security sector reform" missions in the Balkans, West Bank, Iraq and Afghanistan, and a civilian protection mission in Chad. In 2004, Brussels even despatched a civilian ESDP mission to Georgia to help the Georgian government to strengthen the rule of law.

An ESDP mission has three obvious advantages in the current crisis in Georgia. First, it is easier and faster to deploy than a UN mission: time is of the essence in the current crisis. Second, it is not threatening and therefore stands a chance of being accepted by the Russians. In this context it should be made clear that any European deployment would have limited aims: it would most definitely not aim to take over from the existing peacekeeping arrangements in South Ossetia and Abkhazia but would assist Russia to withdraw in an orderly manner from those areas it agreed to withdraw from under the latest ceasefire agreement. Third, the EU is now reasonably experienced in the areas of "soft security" – border monitoring, policing and police training, civilian protection, strengthening rule of law – that an ESDP mission is likely to have to deal with in Georgia.

Remove the cold war rhetoric from the equation and it is quite possible that the Russian government, having made its point to Georgia and to the world, actually now has a political interest in withdrawing from the areas of Georgia its forces have occupied over the past couple of weeks. But Georgian security capacities have been squashed and there are real questions about how to manage such a withdrawal without jeopardising the safety of civilians, and how to allow the swift and safe return of those who have been displaced to their homes.

A limited ESDP civilian protection mission would address those questions, boost the confidence of civilian populations on both sides of the conflict, and help the Russians to honour their agreement to withdraw.

But the EU needs to move fast at a number of levels to make it happen. It needs to work round the clock diplomatically to persuade the Russians that such a mission is in Russia's interests as well as Georgia's and the EU's. It needs to design a concept of operations for what will be one of the EU's most ambitious, high profile and multifaceted ESDP mission thus far. And it needs to pull together the military, police and logistical personnel required for such a force.

If it worked, an ESDP mission in Georgia mandated to protect civilians would be a huge feather in the EU's cap, a validation of its "soft power" approach to foreign affairs and conflict management, as well as a service to the thousands of civilians who have already suffered so terribly in this conflict and who badly need the EU's protection.

BBC Worldwide has come under attack for being "out of control" in the expansion of its business interests, highlighted by the £75m deal with travel publisher Lonely Planet, from an Edinburgh TV festival panel including Time Out founder Tony Elliott.

Elliott, who has written a letter to the Office of Fair Trading over the Lonely Planet deal, said that his company's own discussions about partnering to licence content online stalled because BBC Worldwide wanted "to own us".

"Imagine how irritated I was to say the least when they purchased Lonely Planet," he said. "The Lonely Planet deal could be a deal too far for BBC Worldwide. It has nothing to do with the core business of BBC Worldwide as far as I can tell."

He also questioned about whether the BBC Trust lacked teeth in governing BBC Worldwide's ambitions.

"Are they paying attention and being rigorous enough with some of these deals. In our investigations of the LP [Lonely Planet] transaction, frankly, today we remain convinced this hasn't been scrutinised to the level of detail, and certainly not publicly, as it should be," Elliott said.

He claimed that letters sent under the freedom of information act by Penguin, publisher of Rough Guide and Eyewitness, had not received responses of "substance" six months after they were sent to the BBC Trust.

"Pathetic really for a public entity," Elliott said, arguing that BBC Worldwide's digital ambitions behind the Lonely Planet deal would scupper Time Out.

"You have to assume there will be distortion in the marketplace and people like us haven't got a prayer of competing," he added.

One of the main thrusts of the criticism in the Edinburgh session, which also came from Wall to Wall chief executive Alex Graham, was the commercial threat posed by BBC Wordwide's move into areas such as launching production companies and buying publishers.

"It is the cultural version of sub prime lending," said Wall, commenting on the brand risk the corporation was taking investing in unproven production start-ups to make programming.

"Is it going to come back and bite the BBC not just financially but reputationally?" he asked. "It [could] take just one serious fuck up for the BBC brand to be seriously damaged. The organisation is in danger of getting out of control."

However, David Moody, director of strategy at BBC Worldwide, said that a lot of the criticism that was directed at the corporation's commercial arm was "long on rhetoric and self interest and short on fact".

Moody added that the organisation had only made a few small investments in production companies. "The idea that we are distorting the market is an absurd one," he said.

BBC Worldwide ploughed £150m back into the core public service part of the corporation and its business interests were "absolutely in tune with BBC values", according to Moody.

He claimed that there was "clear blue water" between the commercial operation and the licence fee-funded BBC that was "rigorously policed" and "well enforced".

Moody said that BBC Worldwide's core function was to exploit BBC intellectual property or, such as in the case of Lonely Planet, go into areas that "pull BBC IP with it".

For Lonely Planet that meant melding 2,000 hours of relevant "under exploited" programming with the travel publisher's brand.

Asked what he would like to see happen to BBC Worldwide, Elliott responded that the "broadcasting side" should go back into the corporation, with other operations sold off.

There's a favoured argument among track and field fans that claims that medals in the sport are the hardest to win at any Olympics, because it is the most international of all the events. It is an argument that has been convenient for UK Athletics on a number of occasions, when all the circumstantial evidence, like the paucity of medals won, had suggested that the sport has underperformed. In Beijing, it has been heard quite often.

But how true is it? The 200-odd federations that comprise the International Association of Athletic Federations include plenty of countries who, to be blunt, are not competitive at the Games: Afghanistan, Guinea-Bissau, Kiribati and American Samoa all had athletes in the men's 100m, for example. Did they make it harder for Simeon Williamson, Craig Pickering and Tyrone Edgar? No, not really. Shanahan Sanitoa, of American Samoa, finished last in his heat in 12.60 seconds. Even Williamson and Pickering, who didn't have the best of times in Beijing, could handle that sort of opposition.

Defining what is competitive is an imprecise science. In a more perfect world, we would probably say that the top eight in each event defines competitiveness, and we would total up the nations of those athletes. But it is Sunday, the Games are winding down, and if there's any chance of catching the flight home, we need a statistical shorthand. So let's advance this hypothesis: if we take the number of nations in the athletics medal table, 42, and divide it by the number of medals, 141 (47 events), we get a coefficient that tells us roughly the chance of any of the competitive nations winning a medal, assuming they were all equal.

Well, the coefficient for athletics is 3.357 and the number of medals for the British team is four. If we divide the second figure by the first, we get what we could call a strike rate. For athletics, the strike rate is 1.192. Apply the same formula to the other major British sports, and we get a figure of 1.235 for swimming, 2.857 for rowing, 3.273 for sailing and 5.185 for cycling. The higher the strike rate, of course, the better the team's performance.

But these figures don't take into account the colour of the medal won. If we do that, by giving gold an arbitrary value of four, silver two and bronze one, we get the following figures: athletics is 2.681 (nine divided by 3.357); swimming 2.882; rowing 6.667; sailing 10.366 and cycling 15.556. The gap is getting larger.

We haven't done with figures yet, though, for there is one more very important ingredient that must go in the mix. Athletics and rowing receive roughly the same grant from UK Sport - an average of £6.5m over the past four years - sailing, swimming and cycling marginally less. But athletics has a huge financial advantage over the other four sports in that it generates very considerable sums through television and sponsorship deals. British Athletics receives £8.5m per year from Norwich Union, now branded as Aviva; from McCain another £1m; and from television sales, including the BBC contract (which expires in December), almost another £8m. The annual revenue for UK Athletics is currently at about £25m and dwarfs the income of the other four sports.

The richest of Britain's Olympic sports has one of the poorest Olympic returns. How has that come about? Well, it's not rocket science. To appoint one senior executive without a background in the sport could be seen as careless. To appoint two is serious negligence. To appoint three is so far off the scale of logicality that it makes string theory look simple.

UK Athletics' performance director, Dave Collins, was a psychologist. The chief executive, Niels de Vos, came in from Sale Sharks rugby union club, and the chairman, Ed Warner, is a city businessman who jogs. Jogging is a flourishing sport, but talk to any of the luminaries who graced British athletics in the 70s and 80s - Brendan Foster, Steve Cram and Ian Stewart for starters - and they will tell about generations of serious athletes, who you would see every night on the streets of the north-east and the midlands, and who formed the backbone of Britain's competing athletics teams. It's joggers you see out on the streets now, and joggers don't produce Olympic champions.

The Dwain Chambers affair illustrates how misplaced the ideas of Collins, de Vos and Warner are. The issues surrounding the case were straightforward: Chambers had taken banned drugs, served a two-year ban under the rules of the sport, and returned to the track to compete.

Even though his first race back was in 2006, de Vos decided that he didn't want Chambers in the Olympic trials, and naively went public with the fact. When it soon became apparent that de Vos could not stop him from competing, you might have thought that the chief executive would have been suitably chastened. But no, the witch-hunt was only beginning.

Many would argue that there is a legitimate case for extending the current ban, but lobbying the relevant bodies is the way forward, pillorying an athlete is not. The Chambers affair dragged on through the summer, monopolised the headlines, and for a variety of reasons, left an unpleasant aftertaste. One was left to wonder whether a white, female, middle-class distance runner would be held up to such public and persistent reprobation if she had tested positive and served her ban. The most distasteful moment of the summer came when, as Chambers received his medal for winning the Olympic trials, the single voice booing belonged to the press officer of UK Athletics, Chris Broadbent, who was sitting next to this correspondent.

The Chambers issue has not gone away. Should the sprinter choose to make a more timely appeal to the courts, the judgment of Justice Mackay implies that he could be successful. If UK Athletics gets dragged back in that mire, it will only be a retrograde step.

The vital issue is to get the sport into some sort of shape before the London Games. There's an enormous amount of work to be done and only four years to do it. To date, UK Athletics has given no indication that they are capable of taking the sport forward and Collins must be the most vulnerable performance director in the Olympic sports. Time is running out.

47 min: Ropey backpass from Cattermole gives something for Anelka to chase, but Pollitt surges out of his box to welly it clear.

48 min: Essien wasn't supposed to last beyond half-time and now perhaps he wishes he hadn't - because Cattermole has just clobbered him with a late tackle that is justly punished with a yellow card.

50 min: A rather aimless start to the second period, with Wigan failing to regain the vibrancy they showed in the first half and Chelsea seemingly happy to play at a slower tempo, even though it hasn't helped them find greater crispness in their passing.

52 min: Ballack slips a lovely ball through to Lampard, whose cross is deflected out for a corner, which is wasted.

54 min: Chelsea have monopolised possession for the last few minutes but because Wigan are doing what Pompey failed so wretchedly to do last week, they're having difficulty carving out openings.

56 min: Figeuroa forces a corner with another of his unfeasibly long throw-ins (which Bosingwa headed behind). It's wasted - Lamparditis is catching.

58 min: I wouldn't say Joe Cole has been anonymous this afternoon - his name is still Joe Cole - but he has been virtually invisible. Scolari has at last managed to spot him and haul him off, introducing Salamon Kalou in his place.

60 min: A wild cross from Deco gets caught by a gust of wind and is carried towards Lampard at the edge of the six-yard box. HE declines to head it, electing instead to attempt … well, what was he attempting? The ball bounced off his foot and dropped 15 yards wide of the goal.

63 min: After a strange period of nothingness, Wigan win a corner. De Ridder's delivery is caught by Cech. That is all.

66 min: The game has gone flatter than the earth in the 15th century. Essien fails to lift the tempo with a humdrum shot from 30 yards that rolls into Pollitt's arms.

68 min: It looked effortless, but Chelsea slowly, methodically opened up Wigan and Essien served Lampard with a low cut-back from the right. A splendid tackle by Cattermole thwarts Lampard just as he was winding up a shot from 10 yards.

72 min: Gradually Chelsea have returned to the team of last season, exerting control without any sparkle. Wigan's resistance is waning because they can't get as much of the ball as they had in the first half, yet their ambition remains intact and if Chelsea don't nab a second, an equaliser is always possible.

74 min: Carvahlo booked for being in the vicinity of a Zaki fall.

77 min: Terry blocks a Palacios shot. "Five Live are taking Steve Bruces tracksuit bottoms to task," reveals Adi Bloomfield-Proust. "That seems a lot more interesting then what is happening on the pitch." I haven't noticed his legwear, Adi, but I'm thankful he is at least wearing some.

79 min: Zaki, who has been highly impressive today, charges past Essien and Carvahlo before winning a corner that Terry nods clear.

80 min: After De Ridder hits the corner flag with a shot, Olivier Kapo is introduced in place of Palacios who, like the match, has run out of steam.

83 min: Kalou and Anelka exchange a tidy one-two before Bramble bounds across to tip the ball behind for a corner. Before it can be taken, Wayne Bridhe comes on for Ashley Cole, who has picked up an injury and limps of looking very sorry for himself. Terry courageously refrains from weeping. Lampard and Deco then muck up a short corner.

84 min: Wigan are going gung-ho: Melchiot is withdrawn for Henri Camara.

87 min: Wigan almost snatch the equalizer! But Cech dived low to push Kapo's drilled 20-yard drive behind. And then rises well to claim the corner too.

88 min: Malouda on for Anelka as mighty Chelsea shut up shop.

90 min: As the clock ticks into time added on, Wigan win a free-kick on the brink of the box. Kapo celebrates by smashing it straight into the wall. "On the radio Matt Jackson said that haranguing referees was part of the profession and driven by players desire to win" blurts Stve Peake. "I think it's more likely that the likes of Terry and Cashley are believers in Tony Blair's notion of meritocracy and think that because they are considerably richer than referees their opinions should carry more weight."

90+ 4min: It's officially all over, though really the game ended at half-time. "After two games Steve Bruce is pointless," says Setanta's commentator, which is a bit harsh. Joe Cole and Frank Lampard - now there are two people who were pointless today.

Preamble: Ahoy there! Welcome to a seaside-themed European grand prix at Spain's spanking new Valencia street circuit. It's not quite Monaco (fewer yachts, less money and – wow – a bridge that's been welded down) but it's great to see an addition to the calendar that is in the heartland of formula one, rather than it's newer and wealthier outposts.

So, the title battle is as hot as ever, with Lewis Hamilton, Kimi Raikkonen and Felipe Massa all slugging it out – and Robert Kubica not out of the equation either. Luckily for us, this is set to be one of the more unpredictable races of the season. A new track always brings an extra challenge for the teams, with no previous data to work with, and a street circuit promises wall-skimming, safety-car inducing madness. Some unusual names were troubling the title contenders during practice and qualifying, although they didn't make it into the top four slots. Let's remind ourselves of the grid:

Predictions: Practice and qualifying all passed by without a major shunt – but are we looking at a pile-up in the opening few laps? Possibly. Some drivers have said the corners are all blind, we know there's next to no run-off and there's some names in the top ten of the grid that we weren't expecting to see. The GP2 races had their fair share of crumpled carbon fibre too, so the formula one team strategists will have had their thinking caps on deciding how to build in the probability of a safety car.

The chances of the top four all having an incident-free race are certainly not 100 per cent – but Massa will be hoping he used up his bad luck in the last race, when his engine blew while he was leading with just three laps to go. Hamilton also had a small grey cloud hovering over his head in Hungary, with a puncture dropping him down the order, while Raikkonen still hasn't managed to get the edge on his team-mate in qualifying. None of these three appear to be completely on song, but Massa looks like a good bet for victory if he doesn't get tangled in any collisions.

One man to keep your eye on is Sebastien Vettel. The baby-faced German set the fastest time in a practice session and in Q2 yesterday. He's quick, by god, and he's wound-up Red Bull's Mark Webber who feels that Toro Rosso's Ferrari engine is better than his own Renault. He is eight places behind Vettel, so you can feel his frustration.

ITV's super commentator Louise Goodman has discovered a grid guy standing in front of Jenson Button's car. Equality at last for formula one's grid-number-holders! Except he wasn't in a lycra suit.

The weather looks very fine in the Spanish port, which was once home to the America's Cup yachting extravaganza. Some dark skies had threatened yesterday's qualifying session, although they did not amount to more than a few drops. It appears that today's race will be fair. Nice weather for seagulls... apart from the one that was laid to rest by Nelson Piquet's car yesterday.

Adrian Sutil of Force India will be starting from the pit lane. it's a shame - he did so well in the Monaco grand prix, but his last-place qualifying slot yesterday means he won't be troubling the top ten here.

Start: Here we go... Massa into lead and Kubica pressuring Hamilton but he holds the BMW at bay. Most cars appeared to make it through safely.

Lap one: Kovalainen made it past Raikkonen at the start. So the front runners are Massa from Hamilton, Kubica, Kovalainen and Raikkonen. Nakajima lost his nose when he bumped Alonso from behind. Poor Alonso, his Renault is being pushed into the garage minus a rear wing. All those locals will be gutted. They may get him out again. He'll be hoping for a long safety car period.

Lap three: Hamilton has set the fastest lap. Coulthard was spun around in the first lap, compounding a difficult weekend for the Scot, who didn't even make it through to Q2.

Lap four: Massa's lead over Hamilton is just under two seconds. Raikkonen, in fifth, is almost seven seconds behind his team-mate. Vettel is holding his own in sixth, ahead of Trulli. Alonso has now got out of his car, to the dismay of the fans.

Lap six: Massa is slowly building his lead over Hamilton. Recent star Timo Glock, in the Toyota, made three places at the start of the race and lies tenth. Coulthard has passed Piquet and is in 16th, behind Sutil. The Force India driver appears to be angrily shouting to his engineer over the radio that he needs to pass team-mate Giancarlo Fisichella who is directly ahead. Calm down dear, it's only the opening few laps. This is a long race.

Lap eight: Coulthard, unsighted, has come together with Sutil. The Red Bull spins but keeps going, minus a small piece of carbon fibre. Sutil will be fuming even more, though his progress shouldn't have been hampered too much.

Rustum Kozain has emailed from Cape Town to say that the GU lap-by-lap combined with the excellent live timing screens on the official f1 website are almost as good as having TV. Jeez, thanks Rustum. What else can I do to help build your image of the new circuit? Well, picture lots of catch fencing, some walls, some bikini-clad babes frolicking in the sea.

Lap 11: Looks like Kubica is having problems and his pit crew may be preparing to do some repairs. He's fallen to 13 secs behind Massa, which is holding up Raikkonen, Vettel and Trulli behind - but giving us a nice battle to watch out for.

Sutil may be a little happier now he's past his team-mate and running in 14th place.

Lap 14: Hamilton is now about five seconds adrift of Massa, who looks ominously strong. We had hoped that there would be some opportunities for overtaking here, but Raikkonen cannot find any way past Kovalainen ahead. The Ferrari driver will once again be kicking himself (not literally, there isn't enough room in the cockpit) for not qualifying higher.

Lap 15: The Ferrari mechanics are out and Massa is in for his first stop. That'll please Hamilton, it means the McLaren had more fuel in qualifying. The stop goes well and Massa comes out behind Kovalainen and ahead of his team-mate! Why hasn't he let Raikkonen through? Oooh, bad strategy call from Ferrari.

Lap 16: Hamilton is absolutely flying. Like a greyhound released from the trap. or something. He's broken the 1min38sec barrier. When will he be pitting?

Lap 17: McLaren's silver-clad pit crew are out and the Brit is in. Short and sweet stop. He comes out behind both Ferraris. Massa is still ahead of Raikkonen.

Lap 18: Kubica has pitted, so too Raikkonen. Both stops went smoothly and Kovalainen now leads. It's still a surprise that we've not seen a safety car yet; the race has been extremely clean and Alonso remains as the only retirement.

Paul Ferrari has emailed to ask whether Massa stayed ahead of Raikkonen to ensure that he would remain at the head of the field and with the advantage over Hamilton when the stops shake out. That sounds like a good bet. Perhaps Massa also sees himself as Ferrari's best chance of claiming the world championship and in his head he's the team's number one, unwilling to move over for anyone.

Lap 21: Kovalainen has now pitted and now lies fourth behind Massa, Hamilton and Kubica. Frontrunners Heidfeld and Glock - in fifth and sixth - have yet to stop. Dare we say it's looking a bit predictable up front? That was the last thing we'd envisaged!

Lap 25: Hamilton continues to give away precious tenths of a second to Massa and is now just over five seconds behind. Michael Schumacher is nodding his approval from the pit wall. I wonder what safety car driver Bernd Maylander is up to? Having a kip? Playing tiddlywinks?

So, readers, what do you make of the Valencia circuit? I'm a bit disappointed, truth be told. Precious little overtaking, backdrop of apartment blocks and cranes, grandstands punctuated by empty seats (not sure whether they were occupied until Alonso went out or not). The red-yellow-blue paintwork on the kerbs is excellent, however, and very distinctive.

Lap 29: One-stopping Glock still hasn't stopped. Arnoux has emailed (Rene, is that you?) to ponder why Raikkonen always performs poorly when Schumacher is around. As he puts it, quick drivers don't forget how to be fast. Mais oui, Rene.

And the latest excitement: Webber over-shot his pit marker.

Lap 31: Glock has pitted, at last, and rejoins ahead of Heidfeld in ninth. Further up the field, Trulli passed Vettel for sixth in the first round of stops.

Lap 33: Coulthard has pitted again. Gavin, from Wales, says the grand prix is boring and he wants a crash. 'Where's Ralf Schumacher when you need him," he asks. Probably at home enjoying some bratwurst and mustard.

Gary Naylor emails: "Never mind Valencia, since we no longer have the Nurburgring nor Spa, not to mention Zandvoort nor Brands, aren't all the circuits rubbish?" But Gary, we do have Spa! Just wait a couple of weeks, until 7 September. I agree about Zandvoort though - another seaside special, but with more character than Valencia. You have to love a circuit with a corner named Tarzan.

Lap 35: Massa continues to lead, and set fastest laps, and is all but 10 seconds ahead of Hamilton. The Britain will be wondering what he can possibly do to win this race - or has he given up and settled for second already? Kubica appears to have got over his earlier problems, while Kovalainen is keeping Raikkonen in check behind him.

Lap 37: Massa pits and is released by the lollipop man at the same time as Sutil's Force India and they narrowly escape clashing. Phew! But Massa may find himself with a penalty for driving away when there was another car passing...

Daryl Hendricks asks why Massa is so much quicker than Hamilton. One theory is that the five helpings of shepard's pie he ate last night have given him the edge. Another is that the Ferrari works its tyres better in hot conditions than the McLarens.

Lap 39: Hamilton has pitted and managed not to kiss another car in the pitlane. Massa, meanwhile, is under investigation after his stop. Hamilton rejoins ahead of Kubica, who has yet to take a second pit, protecting his second place. Or could that become first, if Massa gets a drive-through..?

Lap 41: Kubica has pitted. Vettel's stop, a couple of laps ago, has kept him ahead of Glock. No word yet on whether leader Massa will get a wrap on the knuckles from the men in blue.

Lap 43: Sutil is out, nudged up against a tyre wall with broken suspension Arnoux says this GP is dull and backs-up Gary Naylor's comments. He adds the Osterreichring to the list of great tracks we'd like to see. But, Rene, what about Dijon?

Lap 44: Disaster! Raikkonen tried to exit the pits with his fuel hose still connected. A mechanic is down and is being attended to by a doctor - he appeared to catch his head on the wheel. The reigning world champion has now lost a place to Trulli.

The stewards have announced that Massa's pit-lane incident will be investigated after the race.

Jeanette Ramsaroop wants an update on homeboy Alonso. My guess: he's sipping sangria in the Renault motorhome. Sorry Jeanette, he went out on the first lap with a broken rear wing. Blame Kazuki Nakajima.

Lap 46: Raikkonen's engine has blown up and he's now retired from sixth place. So no points for the reigning world champion. Things go from bad to worse for Ferrari and not just in this race. Two engine failures from two races will have the Scuderia big wigs sobbing into their chianti.

When the flag falls on this race, will we know who the winner is? What kind of penalty could Massa be facing? It seems like a very strange decision by the race stewards to delay this investigation. One can only guess that there is information they need that is not readily available.

Lap 49: Massa - who could be facing a grid place penalty in the next race - leads from Hamilton, Kubica, Kovalainen, Trulli, Vettel, Glock, Rosberg, Heidfeld and Bourdais in the top ten. If the order stays like that this will be a great race for Toyota and Toro Rosso teams.

Lap 52: Will there be any changes in position in these final few laps? Hamilton is almost seven seconds adrift of Massa, so there should be no challenge there. Kovalainen is four secs away from Kubica, with a similar gap between Trulli and Vettel.

Paul Ferrari thinks the stewards have it wrong if Massa gets penalised for his pit lane near-miss and Raikkonen receives no penalty for his drama. The difference is that Massa clearly broke a rule, regardless of the outcome. Raikkonen's incident was unfortunate, but was not done on purpose. Unless there's a rule: 'thou shalt not drive over your crew'.

The flag: Felipe Massa has dominated this race and now he takes the victory - which will go some way to making up for his disappointment in the last race. But will it be bittersweet? That's for the stewards to decide. Hamilton is second, but thanks to Raikkonen's misfortune his championship lead is extended by a point. Kubica takes his sixth podium finish.

What it means: Massa's win has moved him into second place in the drivers' title standings. Hamilton leads on 70 points, over Massa on 64 and Raikkonen on 57... with Kubica just two points adrift from the trio. A superb performance from Vettel nets him sixth place, while Rosberg steals a rare point for Williams in eighth. There's unfinished business, however, and we await the outcome of the stewards' investigation into Massa's second pit stop.

"Hey Joe," Jimi Hendrix bellowed in 1966, instantly blighting the lives of people called Joseph for decades to come: "Where you goin' with that gun in your hand?!"

Had Joe been a 27-year-old megalomaniacal rock star instead of a jealous fictional lunatic, he'd probably have replied, "I'm off to extinguish my life before I hit 28, just like you and scores of other drug-addled musicians. Now stop distracting me with stupid questions while I'm trying to immortalise myself!"

At least, that's the kind of macabre age-specific myth currently being lauded by Camden's Proud Gallery which last week launched a photographic exhibition glorifying five rock icons (out of a total of 30) who kicked the bucket aged 27, mostly from drug overdoses. "Forever 27" features artily-grouped pictures of Hendrix, Brian Jones, Janis Joplin and Jim Morrison (who all died between 1969 and 1971) showcased alongside prints of Kurt Cobain, who reportedly idolised the "27 Club" and messily torpedoed his head in order to join them.

When I visited the exhibition, I hoped it'd be full of subheadings like "What an idiot – you had everything, and you threw it away!" and "Why the hell did you blow your brains out? You had a one-year-old daughter!" Instead, it boasted a poster advertising "rock 'n' roll's most infamous members' club", lamenting that the Famous Five were "ill-fated stars whose lives have been tragically cut short at the age of 27", as though they were all killed when a freak piece of errant scaffolding fell on their heads, instead of self-destructing by shovelling drugs into their own mouths and gulping.

Still, if they'd been mistakenly decapitated, cruelly obliterated by a flying stapler or hit by a dustcart aged 83 after living long, enjoyable lives, they probably wouldn't be as "iconic", and Proud wouldn't be able to flog their photos for up to £950. Death and youth sell, especially when you tie a group of early deaths together in an apparently eerie, "much-mythologised" way. "Does a nihilistic instinct kick in at the age 27?" the subtext muses. Er, no: I just had a whole year of being 27, and I didn't want to top myself once, but then I didn't spend it wandering around wanky photographic exhibitions. "Jim Morrison and Brian Jones both spookily died on July 3" is the other main 27 Club observation. Yeah? Well, I was born on July 3. That's what's known as a coincidence.

They aren't the only ones cashing in on the unnecessary 27 Club deaths though: you can also buy a book online about "the greatest myth of rock 'n' roll" (interestingly, its blurb fails to mention all the rock stars who also died at 26 and 28) and for a credit-crunching £22, you can buy a 27 Club t-shirt online (modelled here by some kind of Jesus-Bono hybrid) emblazoned with the five dead club members and a Neil Young lyric misquoted from Cobain's suicide note: "It's better to burn out rather [sic] than fade away." Hmm … is it really? Wouldn't most people rather live a long and peaceful life than choke on their own acrid carroty vomit barely a third of the way through?

Camden is a poor area of London, and there are lots of things it needs, but an exhibition romanticising early drug-related deaths isn't one of them. What it needs far more, in among all its dealers and junkies, is a celebration of life. The space at Proud could be better used to tell the stories of ordinary people who were penniless and anonymous, but still made the very most of every moment instead of obliterating themselves. As Oasis's songwriter Noel Gallagher said of Cobain in the early 1990s: "Seems to me that here was a guy who had everything, and was miserable about it. And we had fuck all, and I still thought that getting up in the morning was the greatest fuckin' thing ever." He insisted, "I can't have people like [Cobain] coming over here, on smack, fucking saying that they hate themselves and they wanna die. That's fucking rubbish. Kids don't need to be hearing that nonsense."

So he decided to write the upbeat single Live Forever as an antidote. It was released in 1994, when Gallagher was that most nihilistic of ages: 27.

A 24-year-old man has been shot dead in Birmingham, West Midlands police said today.

The man, who has not been named, was shot last night in the Newtown area. He was taken to hospital where he was later pronounced dead.

It is the third fatal shooting in the area in less than a year. On March 18 Nehemiah Bryce, 27, of Winson Green, was shot dead a few hundred metres from last night's attack. On December 23 last year, Assar Joseph Mohammed Tomlinson was killed during a row in Newtown.

Last night's shooting took place in Hockley Close. A spokesman for West Midlands Ambulance Service said they had received a call at 10.13pm.
"An ambulance was on scene within three minutes of the call and was backed up by a rapid response vehicle," he said. "A 24-year-old man was taken on blue lights to City hospital. The paramedic from the response vehicle travelled with the ambulance crew to provide additional assistance as the man was treated en route to hospital.

"Sadly, despite the best efforts of ambulance and hospital staff it was not possible to save the man and he was confirmed dead at hospital."

"We are asking them to give up everything," admits Melanie Chowns, her soft voice rising above the hollow chatter of thundersticks at Beijing's National Indoor Stadium. "It's one thing chasing the Olympic dream, it's quite another moving to Denmark."

Chowns, the manager of Great Britain's women's handball squad, is outlining her sport's ambitious plans to create men and women's teams strong enough to reach the knockout stages in London 2012 - a huge task for a country that has never played in an Olympic handball tournament and has less than 1,000 registered players.

It is, in effect, a great sporting engineering project, involving a nationwide hunt for tall sporty converts, £3.3m of lottery funding over three years and counting, jaw-dropping self sacrifice and, yes, Denmark.

For the past 18 months, most of Britain's leading players have been living at the Aarhus Handball Academy, training six hours a day and playing in the national league, one of the strongest in Europe. "Each player is evaluated every six months and if we decide they're not good enough they're out," says performance director Bill Baillie. "We've never hid it from them. The pressure is always there."

No one knows this better than Lynn McCafferty, the captain of the women's team. "I got married last year and my husband plays handball as well," she says. "He had his chance - he was on the programme, got injured and fell back a couple of months, and lost his place. He's now back in our house in Glasgow working in insurance, while I'm in Denmark."

How does that feel? "It's very hard," she says. "We've spent the last nine months living apart. But you have to put handball first or you'll never make it."

Partly because the sporting gene pool exposed to handball is so small, the British Handball Association has been an enthusiastic embracer of UK Sport's various Talent ID programmes for London 2012. Last year's Sporting Giants campaign, which sought tall, athletic types to try out for volleyball, rowing and handball was particularly successful: of the 4,000 applicants, 12 are now training in Denmark in British handball's development programme.

"We sat down with UK Sport and went through the criteria we were looking for," explains Chowns. "Skills in ball sports were desirable, height essential. We were looking for a minimum of 5ft 11in for women and 6ft 6in for men." Initially 120 men, mainly from a rugby or basketball background, and 60 women, most of whom played netball, were selected for trials. After a series of physical and aptitude tests, and several camps in the UK and Denmark, eight men and four women accepted offers to move to Denmark full time. "It was a bit like X-Factor," admits Chowns. "We had all the photos on the wall and debated the rationale behind picking each player."

One of those who made the grade was 18-year-old Laura Innes, an A-level student who had never played handball in her life until last year. "I filled in the form on the internet, didn't hear anything for a while, went to my first training session and it all went from there," she says. "London 2012 is always on my mind but there's a long way to go."

Innes was at these Olympics as part of a six-strong handball team, and a much bigger squad of British development athletes across 33 sports. None of them competed, that wasn't the point. Instead they spent a week in Macau and Beijing as part of an immersion programme that the British Olympic Association hopes will help bring medals, rather than stagefright, when these athletes make their Olympic debuts in 2012.

Will our handball teams be able to step up? "Making the knockout stages will certainly be tough," says Baillie. "Our men are probably ranked about 30th in Europe, and the women are there or thereabouts too. But we've made massive strides in the last 18 months; our players are playing in higher divisions in Denmark and they're improving all the time."

They're still a long way behind the sport's powerhouses - the likes of Germany, Russia, Denmark and France, who beat surprise packages Iceland in the men's final earlier today. But even if British handball crashes and burns in four years' time, Baillie is convinced London 2012 will turn out to be a watershed moment for his sport.

"In the Sydney Olympics, handball was voted the most popular spectator sport," he points out. "But their handball association wasn't ready for the demand that followed. They had one man and a dog in the office and they were getting 6,000 calls a day. They couldn't deal with it and the chance to develop in Australia died.

"We're already putting plans in place to ensure that doesn't happen," he adds, voice bristling with determination. "Take it from me: London 2012 really will bring a legacy for our sport."

The President of the International Olympic Committee Jacques Rogge said today that Great Britain's medal success in Beijing has been a powerful boost for the 2012 Games in London, where he expects the host nation will be able to do even better than the 19 golds and 47 total medals that secured fourth place in the medals table.

"The British team is ready and that's important because we want a powerful and successful home team to foster the enthusiasm of the whole population," Rogge said. "That has been achieved four years beforehand, and they will be able to improve even on that."

Rogge warned however that London faces a tough task to match Beijing, which has had spectacular ceremonies, more than a million volunteers, and unprecedented control over areas such as transport, labour, resources and
security. "It's clear that China has put the bar very high and it's going
to be a challenge for London and also for all the subsequent Games," Rogge said.

"I believe London has unique assets," he added. "Athens was returning to the roots, to the country that invented the Olympic Games. China was the most populous country in the world. London is the capital city of the country that has invented modern sport, that has invented the rules of the sports, and the values of fair play.

"It is a cosmopolitan, multi-ethnic and multi-religious city and that's
something they can build on. The rest have no concerns. The venues will be fine, the village will be fine, the organisation will be fine."

Discriminatory policies against Italy's Romany Gypsy population, including the fingerprinting of children, are said to have their origins in the fascist policies of Mussolini. Many were shocked by the apathy shown when two Gypsy girls drowned on a beach near Naples, as people carried on enjoying their day out only yards away, regardless of the small bodies laid out on the sand. But how different is Britain when it comes to prejudice against its own travelling people?

According to a report last year from the Children's Society, almost nine out of every 10 children and young people with a Gypsy background have been the victim of racial abuse. The report also stated that nearly two-thirds have been bullied or physically attacked.

Few campsites are provided for British Gypsies, and draconian powers allow local authorities to crack down on new encampments. Shelter Scotland points out that if you are a Gypsy and you own your own land, you can still be evicted by your local council. Ernie Rutherford, Romany Gypsy and professional boxing trainer, told me:

There ain't no life on the road no more. You'll end up living in a house – that's just the way it is. That's how they're killing it out. They take away our lifestyle and make us fit in with everybody else's … In the end there won't be no Gypsies – that's the way it's going. We can't even buy some land and put nothing on it, because they'll bulldoze it down. At the end of the day they don't want to give us nowhere to live, they don't want us to drive about on the road, they don't really want to give us houses.

When I ask him whether he thinks Gypsies are discriminated against, he says, "Yeah, you're not wrong. We're the only people now that you can call pikey and things like that on the telly and get away with it. Catherine Tate takes the piss out of us every week mate." This makes me glad that Tate didn't win the British Comedy award.

Rutherford grew up in St Mary Cray, in south-east London, which is the largest settled community of Romany Gypsies, or Travellers, in the UK. Like many Gypsies, the Rutherfords lived in pre-fabricated asbestos housing until the site was eventually closed down and they were moved into houses. "Them houses were the worst houses in the area – they were dangerous," he recalls. Not Kushti Atchin Tan, or a good stopping place, in the Roma language.

Ernie tells me how some of his family have had bricks thrown through the windows of their caravans when they've been on the road. "Some people don't like you in their area, they don't want you there. They look on us as we're the worst kind of people in this country," he says. He just wants to be treated with respect. The government does not provide sites for the Travellers, but he would love to buy a plot of land and put a mobile home on it. He accepts that at the moment this is an almost impossible dream.

"If the government can't control ya, then they don't want ya," he believes. "They talk about China and all these places, they're just as bad. They ain't no different, they just do it craftily." He complains that there are no schools for Traveller people. "They're killing our culture that's what they're doing. They're doing it slowly, but they're doing a good job of it."
